security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate educational and documentation skill for building MCP servers. All code uses official MCP SDK libraries for expected functionality (stdio, SSE, HTTP transport connections). Network calls are to MCP servers only. No data exfiltration, credential theft, or malicious patterns detected.

content.user_title: Build MCP servers for LLM tool integration
content.value_statement: Creating MCP servers requires following protocol best practices for tool design, authentication, and testing. This skill provides step-by-step guidance for implementing servers in Python or TypeScript that enable LLMs to interact with external services through well-designed tools.
actual_capabilities: Guide MCP protocol specification study and framework setup
Implement MCP servers in Python (FastMCP) or TypeScript (MCP SDK)
Design tools with proper naming, input validation, and annotations
Create evaluation tests to verify LLM effectiveness with servers
Configure transport layers (stdio, SSE, HTTP) and authentication
Apply security best practices for API key handling and input validation
limitations: Does not execute external API calls directly on user behalf
Requires user to implement actual server code following guidance
Does not provide pre-built servers for specific services
Evaluation scripts require Anthropic API key and external MCP server

use_cases.title: Create Custom Integrations
use_cases.description: Build MCP servers to connect LLMs with internal APIs and services for custom workflows.

use_cases.title: Standardize Tool Design
use_cases.description: Apply MCP best practices for consistent, discoverable tool naming and response formats.

use_cases.title: Test Server Quality
use_cases.description: Create evaluation questions to verify LLMs can effectively use tools for complex tasks.

prompt_templates.title: Build GitHub MCP Server
prompt_templates.scenario: Create Python server for GitHub API
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an MCP server in Python using FastMCP for the GitHub API. Include tools to list repositories, create issues, and search code. Follow the naming convention {service}_mcp and use Pydantic models for input validation.

prompt_templates.title: Add Tool Validation
prompt_templates.scenario: Improve input validation on existing server
prompt_templates.prompt: Add Zod schema validation to an existing TypeScript MCP server. Create strict input schemas with proper error messages. Ensure all required fields have appropriate constraints and descriptions.

prompt_templates.title: Create Evaluations
prompt_templates.prompt: Create 10 evaluation questions for an MCP server that test whether LLMs can find specific information using only the provided tools. Questions should require multiple tool calls and have single verifiable answers.

prompt_templates.title: Configure HTTP Transport
prompt_templates.prompt: Configure a TypeScript MCP server to use streamable HTTP transport instead of stdio. Include proper authentication via environment variables and set up an Express endpoint for client connections.

output_examples.input: Create an MCP server for a weather API that provides current conditions and forecasts
output: Input validation: Pydantic models with location, units, and date parameters
Response formats: JSON for programmatic use, Markdown for readability

best_practices: Use consistent naming conventions: {service}_mcp for Python, {service}-mcp-server for TypeScript
Include service prefix in all tool names to prevent conflicts when using multiple servers
Support both JSON and Markdown response formats to accommodate different use cases
Implement proper pagination with limit, offset, and has_more fields for list operations
anti_patterns: Using generic tool names like 'get_data' or 'search' without service prefix
Returning all data without pagination or filtering, overwhelming LLM context
Hardcoding API keys or credentials in server source code
Missing tool annotations (readOnlyHint, destructiveHint, idempotentHint) that help LLMs understand tool behavior

faq.question: Which programming language should I use for my MCP server?
faq.answer: TypeScript (MCP SDK) and Python (FastMCP) are both officially supported. TypeScript offers strong SDK support and works well with AI code generation. Python is ideal if your API has Python SDKs or your team prefers Python.

faq.question: What transport should I choose for my MCP server?
faq.answer: Use stdio for local integrations and development tools. Use streamable HTTP for remote servers that serve multiple clients. SSE is deprecated in favor of streamable HTTP.

faq.question: How do I secure my MCP server authentication?
faq.answer: Store API keys in environment variables only. Never hardcode credentials. Validate tokens on startup. Use OAuth 2.1 for services that support it. Provide clear error messages without exposing internal details.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using MCP servers?
faq.answer: MCP servers run locally or on your infrastructure. Data only flows between your server and the target API. The skill itself does not collect, store, or transmit any user data. Authentication credentials remain in your environment.

faq.question: How do I test if my MCP server tools work well?
faq.answer: Create evaluation questions that require multiple tool calls. Test whether LLMs can discover and use your tools correctly. The evaluation guide provides 10 question criteria: independent, read-only, complex, realistic, verifiable, and stable answers.

faq.question: How does this compare to building REST APIs?
faq.answer: MCP servers are designed specifically for LLM consumption with structured tool definitions, automatic schema generation, and annotations that help LLMs understand capabilities. REST APIs require additional wrapper logic for LLM integration. MCP provides better discoverability and type safety for AI agents.
